repnme.cdata!: Russian Federation - Moscow Urban Transport Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Moscow Urban Transport
            Project for Russian Federation were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low
            or negligible, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            experience under this project is a worthwhile contribution
            to the long-standing debate on whether Project
            Implementation Unit (PIU) should be set as separate units,
            to maximize implementation efficiency, or within partner
            institutions, to contribute to institution building. This
            project opted for the former. The rationale for using the
            Moscow foundation as a PIU was based on their excellent
            performance under the Bridge Rehabilitation Project (then in
            the final phase), and on the fact that the major agreed
            investment under the new project was a large-scale bridge
            complex. It will have been both risky and counter-productive
            to give the inexperienced Traffic Management Center (TMC),
            which had just been set up, the responsibility to manage the
            implementation of a large-scale investment, especially since
            this type of investment was not going to be within their
            future purview. The project's main concern was to have
            TMC with sufficient and properly qualified staff, the right
            premises and equipment, authority and organization to carry
            out a set of essential traffic management functions, and
            entry into decision making processes of Moscow City
            Government (MCG). Early missions noted that the agreed
            staffing quotas were met by TMC, but not proper
            qualifications and experience. Later missions focused on the
            transfer of staff versed in traffic signal control from the
            police to TMC, and much less on the matter of exact
            qualifications for other traffic management activities. The
            project certainly did well in this respect, especially
            regarding the traffic police component, where the new skills
            supplemented by modern equipment raised qualifications
            relatively quickly. Still, much more intensive training and
            of longer duration is needed to re-educate civil engineers
            for careers in traffic management. For future projects that
            focus on institution building of this type, it is
            recommended to take the education and career aspects as
            seriously as engineering, financial and economic aspects.
            This will require enlarging the scope of preparation to
            include national universities and technical colleges,
            possibly resulting in project-funded support for an
            expansion of the relevant course programs, within the same
            or under a separate project.

repnme.cdata!: Russian Federation - Moscow Urban Transport Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Moscow Urban Transport Project aims
            at improving institutional capacity in planning,
            implementing, operating, and enforcing traffic management
            measures, to improve transport mobility in the city. The
            components will: 1) finance the establishment of a traffic
            management center (TMS), responsible for planning traffic
            management schemes, including the operation of traffic
            signals. Technical assistance, and training will be provided
            to support implementation by the TMS, of traffic monitoring
            programs, and studies on traffic control, and parking
            availability; 2) include a comprehensive range of traffic,
            and safety enhancing improvements along two corridors,
            radiating from the Garden Ring, to the Outer Ring Road
            encircling Moscow, including an additional corridor to be
            determined; 3) finalize completion of feasibility studies
            for the Garden Ring/Central Area, begun during project
            preparation. Upon approval, completion of detailed
            engineering schemes along the above mentioned area, will be
            financed; 4) widen the Donbasky Bridge, to accommodate an
            eight lane roadway on either side of the bridge, and,
            eliminate the existing tram track bridge; and, 5) conduct a
            traffic enforcement program, ensuring adequate training to
            staff, and implementation of operational plans to maximize
            equipment, construction, and advisory investments.

repnme.cdata!:
Russian Federation - Moscow Urban Transport
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
It is expected that during construction
            of the Moscow Urban Transport Project, potential adverse
            environmental impacts will occur. This environmental
            assessment provides a chart on the environmental impacts,
            and concerns, and offers mitigating measures as follows: 1)
            civil works call for test soils on contaminants, in
            compliance with current national regulations. Contaminated
            soils will be disposed of at approved sites, by specialized
            agencies to recover, and dispose contaminated waste. Trees
            and vegetation damaged as a result of road widening, will be
            protected in accordance with regulations, and standards,
            replaced, and/or replanted; 2) noise, and dust disturbance
            should be abated by limiting working schedules, as
            restricted by the project design, and, equipment should have
            noise-suppression devices; 3) adversity on cultural heritage
            sites will be avoided through careful project design, and,
            protective archaeological measures will ensure those sites
            thus far unknown; 4) alternative measures for safe traffic,
            and accessibility will be provided, and enforced by city
            officials, including promotion of public transit use; and,
            5) in the case of land acquisition, adequate compensation
            will be provided to landowners, in accordance with city
            regulations, and World Bank guidelines.
